mainText:
He had also done work on the bliss point, showing how a product’s allure is contextual, shaped partly by the other foods a person is eating, and that it changes as people age.
Toppels, a cracker with cheese topping; Stuffers, a shell with a variety of fillings; Rumbles, a bite-size granola snack — they all came and went in a blink, and the company took a $52 million hit.
The largest single block of customers, the baby boomers, had begun hitting middle age.
According to the research, this suggested that their liking for salty snacks — both in the concentration of salt and how much they ate — would be tapering off.
Around that time, the marketing team was joined by Dwight Riskey, an expert on cravings who had been a fellow at the Monell Chemical Senses Center in Philadelphia, where he was part of a team of scientists that found that people could beat their salt habits simply by refraining from salty foods long enough for their taste buds to return to a normal level of sensitivity.
This seemed to help explain why Frito-Lay was having so much trouble selling new snacks.
The company had introduced a series of high-profile products that failed miserably.
Not much had changed by 1986, except Frito-Lay found itself on a rare cold streak.
Along with the rest of the snack-food industry, Frito-Lay anticipated lower sales because of an aging population, and marketing plans were adjusted to focus even more intently on younger consumers.

title: The Extraordinary Science of Addictive Junk Food - NYTimes.com
